thread.title: UIL enters gender politics debate with proposed birth certificate requirement
thread.title_full: UIL enters gender politics debate with proposed birth certificate requirement | Dallas Morning News

author: Corbett Smith
title: UIL enters gender politics debate with proposed birth certificate requirement
text:
ROUND ROCK - The University Interscholastic League is finally set to wade into the contentious debate of gender-identity politics.
On Monday, the UIL's Legislative Council asked the state's superintendents to approve a measure that would use a birth certificate to determine a student-athlete's gender.
According to the league's policy director, Jamey Harrison, the proposed rule - placed on a referendum ballot that will likely be sent out at the start of next year - isn't a change in the league's current procedure; the league already advises districts to use birth certificates when questions of gender arise.
The significance, however, is in the league setting that rule in stone.
If passed, Texas would officially become one of the more restrictive states in the nation for transgender students.
Chris Mosier, founder of the advocacy group TransAthlete.com, called the measure a "horrible policy" that would deny equal access to participation for the state's transgender students.
"Categorizing transgender student athletes by their birth certificates is among the least inclusive policies at the high school level," Mosier wrote in a statement to The Dallas Morning News . "High school athletics should focus on enabling participation, not restricting it."
According to research by TransAthlete, athletic organizations in 15 states - ranging from California to Wyoming - and the District of Columbia have policies that allow students to participate in activities consistent with their gender identity. Five states -Alabama, Georgia, Idaho, New Mexico and North Carolina - have policies that TransAthlete views as discriminatory, with four of them using a birth certificate to determine gender.
Mosier added that there is no research to support the idea that allowing a transgender girl to compete would create a competitive imbalance.
One of the members of the Legislative Council to speak out during Monday's meeting, Barbers Hill ISD's Greg Poole, said that his sole interest in the rule was "fair and equitable competition," not to "cast stones at anyone's personal choice."
In previous meetings with UIL staff, Poole had lobbied that the league should be even more restrictive, requiring the student-athlete's original birth certificate, before being advised otherwise by the UIL's legal counsel.
The league has a "non-discrimination" policy in its constitution, stating that no student shall be denied an equal opportunity to compete in sports because of disability, race, color, gender, religion or national origin - with certain caveats. But the league hadn't taken steps to officially define gender until Monday.
The new rule adds a subsection which states that: "Gender shall be determined based on a student's birth certificate. In cases where a student's birth certificate is unavailable, other similar government documents used for the purpose of identification may be substituted."
The change was one of over 60 revisions put in front of the council for approval on Monday; the UIL is rewriting its entire constitution, one of the directives requested from the Sunset Review process the league finished earlier this year.
